thread.title_full: Unions warn BlueScope deal ''no greenlight'' for employers | afr.com

author: Ewin Hannan
title: Unions warn BlueScope deal ''no greenlight'' for employers
text:
Scott McDine: "I don't think anyone should be forming the view ... that this is a new standard." Romy Photography by Ewin Hannan Unions have warned employers they will fight attempts to use the ground-breaking workplace agreement at BlueScope Steel to cut jobs and conditions at struggling businesses.
The Australian Workers Union said on Friday the extraordinary deal reached with BlueScope, including 500 job losses and a three-year pay freeze, reflected the "unique circumstances" facing the nation's biggest steelworks.
Scott McDineâ€‹, the AWU's national secretary, said unions would treat enterprise bargaining negotiations with companies on a "case-by-case basis".
"I don't think anyone should be forming the view or making the assumption that this is a new standard," he said.
University of Adelaide professor Andrew Stewart said on Friday he believed some companies would look at what BlueScope had achieved and seek to replicate the deal.
"It seems to me to be natural that some other businesses under pressure are going to look at this and say, can we get similar arrangements?" Professor Stewart said.
"We don't have a major history in this country of what the Americans call concession bargaining. The system is flexible enough for that to happen. With the economy going as flat as it is, we are going to see other companies look at this."
A potential industrial flashpoint looms at Arrium's Whyalla steelworks in South Australia where the company wants to cut jobs and overhaul work practices.
 The embattled steel, mining, and materials group is seeking an additional $100 million of cost savings in its steel arm, OneSteel, on top of $60 million of previously announced savings.
The company declined to comment on Friday on whether the BlueScope agreement had implications for its approach to its upcoming negotiations with unions, including the AWU.
But Mr McDine made it clear on Friday that the company should not be encouraged by the concessions given by unions to BlueScope management.
"All companies, including the likes of OneSteel and Arrium, should not see this as a green light," he said.
The dramatic concessions at BlueScope, which also include an effective strike freeze, follows the company's warning in August that $60 million in costs, including 500 jobs, would have to be cut at Port Kembla or it would close the plant and import commodity steel .
The union concessions are contingent on the company board deciding to keep the Port Kembla. Sources said the agreement achieved $170 million in cuts and would require an injection of about $30 million from the NSW government to reach the company's target.
But the company's bid to achieve payroll tax and other concessions from the state government is yet to be secured. A spokesman for NSW Industry Minister Anthony Roberts, has said the government remained in productive discussions with BlueScope ahead of the board considering the ongoing viability of the steelworks.
Mr McDine called on NSW Premier Mike Baird to deliver the payroll tax relief. He said the state government was "sitting on its hands" and needed to make a decision.
